citations.narrative:
Medical records of two adult California Sea Lions, Lilly and Zoey, provided to the inspector are outdated and incomplete.
Lilly's medical record states she is to receive "tacrolimus in both eyes SID" but no tacrolimus is on hand during inspection.
There is no documentation of this treatment. Zoey was observed squeezing her left eye shut intermittently during
inspection. Zoey's medical record does not state treatment plans for eye drops, but the facility representative is
administering 5 drops of cyclosporine in both eyes as needed. There is no documentation of this treatment. The attending
veterinarian confirmed that both animals are under veterinary care and current treatment and monitoring is aligned with
their authority and direction. Failure to fully document required information in medical records can lead to missed
treatments and unresolved medical issues.
Individual animal medical records must be kept and made available for APHIS inspection. These medical records must
include at least the information in this subpart 3.110(d), which includes identification of all medical and physical problems
with proposed plan of action, all diagnostic test results and documentation of treatment.
Correct by 10 April 2025.
This inspection was conducted at Maricopa County Fair in Phoenix, Arizona.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.110(d)(2) 
   
Veterinary care. 
Medical records of two adult California Sea Lions, Lilly and Zoey, provided to the inspector are outdated and incomplete. 
Lilly's medical record states she is to receive "tacrolimus in both eyes SID" but no tacrolimus is on hand during inspection. 
There is no documentation of this treatment. Zoey was observed squeezing her left eye shut intermittently during 
inspection. Zoey's medical record does not state treatment plans for eye drops, but the facility representative is 
administering 5 drops of cyclosporine in both eyes as needed. There is no documentation of this treatment. The attending 
veterinarian confirmed that both animals are under veterinary care and current treatment and monitoring is aligned with 
their authority and direction. Failure to fully document required information in medical records can lead to missed 
treatments and unresolved medical issues. 
 
Individual animal medical records must be kept and made available for APHIS inspection. These medical records must 
include at least the information in this subpart 3.110(d), which includes identification of all medical and physical problems 
with proposed plan of action, all diagnostic test results and documentation of treatment.  
 
Correct by 10 April 2025. 
 
This inspection was conducted at Maricopa County Fair in Phoenix, Arizona. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
